choices.choice: only provide position in latitude and longitude
indicate two-dimension positions or position lines in the horizontal plane.

question: Satellites used in GNSS< orbit the earth:
explanation: GNSS (Global Navigation Satellite System) satellites, like those in GPS, orbit the Earth approximately every 12 hours. Specifically, they orbit at a medium Earth orbit (MEO) around 20,000 km altitude, meaning they circle the planet once every 11 hours, 58 minutes, and 2 seconds. This orbital period is crucial for providing continuous global coverage
subject: Navigation

question: It may be claimed that GNSS has the advantage over other air navigation systems in that it:

choices.choice: is basically a military-based system made available to civil users with solar-powered satellites which have an infinite life.
has no possible input by the pilot

subject: Navigation

question: Position fixing by satellite is by means of :

choices.choice: simultaneous bearings from a number of satellites
range and bearing from each known satellite's position
simultaneous ranges from a number of satellites.

explanation:
Position fixing by satellite (like GPS) is done by measuring simultaneous ranges from multiple satellites.

This method is called trilateration.

üõ∞Ô∏è How it works:

  • Each satellite sends a signal with the exact time it was transmitted.

  • The receiver on the aircraft (or any GPS device) notes the time it took for each signal to arrive.

  • Using this time, it calculates the distance (range) to each satellite.

  • By calculating simultaneous ranges from at least 4 satellites, the receiver can determine:

    • Latitude

    • Longitude

    • Altitude

    • Precise time
subject: Navigation

question: The GPS transmission frequency which can be used by civil aircraft is:
subject: Navigation

question: The minimum number of satellites required for a 3D fix is:
explanation:
The minimum number of satellites required for a 2D fix is three, and the minimum number required for a 3D fix is four:

  • 2D fix

    A receiver needs to lock onto the signal of at least three satellites to calculate a 2D position (latitude and longitude). The last acquired altitude is assumed.

  • 3D fix

    A receiver needs to lock onto the signal of at least four satellites to calculate a 3D position (latitude, longitude, and altitude). 

The GPS uses triangulation to determine a position. A GPS receiver measures distance by using the travel time of a radio signal.
subject: Navigation

question: The orbital height and inclination of the NAVSTAR/GPS constellation are:
explanation: The NAVSTAR/GPS satellites orbit the Earth at an altitude of approximately 20,200 kilometers (12,550 miles) and are inclined 55 degrees from the equator. This configuration allows for a global coverage of at least four satellites from any point on Earth.
subject: Navigation

question: The reason that the satellites of GPS and GLONASS do not collide is:

choices.choice: the GPS orbit is at 55¬∞ to the equator while the GLONASS is at 60¬∞
the GPS satellite orbits are 1200 km higher than the GLONASS orbits
GLONASS has only three orbital planes while GPS has six orbital planes.

subject: Navigation

question: Satellite geometry error is greatest when:
explanation:
Satellite geometry error is greatest when satellites are closest together. When satellites are close in the sky, the "dilution of precision" (DOP) is high, indicating poor geometry and increased uncertainty in the calculated position. This is because the angles between the satellites and the receiver are less distinct, making it harder to pinpoint the exact location.

  • Example:

    Imagine trying to pinpoint the location of a point by looking at the intersection of two circles (representing satellite range). If the circles are far apart, the intersection is smaller and easier to define. If the circles are close together, the intersection is larger and harder to define.
subject: Navigation

question: NAVSTAR/GPS operates in the _______ band and the receiver determines position by ________
explanation:
Range Position Lines (RPLs):

  • A Range Position Line (RPL) represents a circle around a satellite, with the radius equal to the distance between the satellite and the receiver (the pseudorange).

  • The satellite is located at the center of the circle, and the receiver lies somewhere on the circle.

  • Example: If the receiver is 20 nm away from the satellite, the RPL is a circle with a radius of 20 nm, and the receiver lies somewhere on that circle.
subject: Navigation

question: The model of the earth used for NAVSTAR/GPS is:
explanation: The NAVSTAR/GPS system uses the WGS-84 (World Geodetic System 1984) ellipsoid as its model of the Earth. WGS-84 is a geodetic reference datum that defines the shape and size of the Earth and is used for positioning and navigation.
subject: Navigation

question: The US DoD degrades GPS accuracy:

choices.choice: to prevent 100% reliance on a system which may have to be interrupted for military purposes at a moment's notice.

subject: Navigation

choices.choice: the time difference between the transmission of the satellite's coded signal and the time that it is received at the aircraft
the time difference between the satellite and the aircraft GPS unit transmitting the same code point on the signal
the correction applied to the 'raw' GPS position to obtain a more precise position.

question: The NAVSTAR/GPS operational constellation comprises ___________ satellites
explanation: The NAVSTAR/GPS operational constellation comprises 24 satellites. The NASA developed the GPS system, which initially used 24 satellites. The constellation is designed with 24 satellites positioned in six orbital planes.
subject: Navigation

question: The accuracy of range measurement of satellite to GPS receiver is:

choices.choice: seriously reduced during periods of sunspot activity
seriously eroded during periods of anomalous propagation in an inversion
derived from accurate timepieces in the satellite and the aircraft's GPS receiver.

subject: Navigation
